Her service to her nation and her courage on that bus over 70 years ago are an inspiration to us all ‚Äì and a powerful reminder of the integral role Black women have played in the fight for racial and gender equality in America. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FqobbR-WYAAigkL.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fqob9fUX0AAPJ28.jpg

Evens' defiant protest took place three years before Rosa Parks famously refused to give up her seat to a white passenger. Though often overshadowed, Evans‚Äô case played a critical role in the fight for civil rights.

The case was filed by DC lawyer Julius Winfield Robertson and his partner, Dovey Johnson Roundtree, a former WAC veteran herself, who also experienced discriminatory treatment on buses. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FqoapjhXsAEE2kc.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FqoapvpWAAAJZex.jpg

Evans‚Äô courageous act paved the way for the landmark case, Sarah Keys v. Carolina Coach Company, which countered the ruling of ‚Äúseparate but equal‚Äù in Plessy v. Ferguson by banning segregation on buses crossing state lines.

On the bus ride home, Evans was ordered by the bus driver to give up her seat to a white Marine, and she adamantly refused. The bus driver then moved all the other passengers to a different bus and Evans was subsequently jailed for 13 hours and fined $25 for disorderly conduct.

In 1951, Sarah Keys Evans enlisted in the Women‚Äôs Army Corps and was stationed at Fort Dix in New Jersey. The following year, Private First Class Keys traveled from Fort Dix to visit her family in North Carolina. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FqoauXTWcAIxlCN.jpg

During #WomensHistoryMonth, we share and uplift the stories of countless women who have broken through social, political, and economic barriers in the ongoing fight for true equality ‚Äì including Sarah Keys Evans, an Army veteran and major figure in the Civil Rights Movement. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FqobSGbWYAExdKr.jpg

To protect our national security, our economy, and our critical infrastructure, it‚Äôs time to stop playing Whac-A-Mole and start adopting a clear, risk-based approach to foreign tech threats. Let‚Äôs pass the RESTRICT Act.

We‚Äôre building momentum to get this done ‚Äì the growing bipartisan coalition for this bill includes @SenatorBaldwin, @SenatorFischer, @Sen_JoeManchin, @JerryMoran, @SenatorBennet, @SenDanSullivan, @SenatorCollins, @SenGillibrand, @MartinHeinrich, and @SenatorRomney.

This is a huge issue ‚Äì so I‚Äôve worked to assemble a bipartisan team to put together a cohesive legislative fix. I‚Äôm proud to be leading this effort with @SenJohnThune ‚Äì because protecting Americans isn‚Äôt a partisan issue.

Particularly when we‚Äôre dealing with technologies that are conduits for Americans‚Äô speech and expression, it‚Äôs vital that any action be risk-based, rule-bound, and carefully balance addressing national security threats with avoiding impacts on Americans‚Äô speech.

We also have to move past the ‚Äòjust trust us‚Äô approach USG has taken in the past in these areas. For that reason, our bill requires Commerce and ODNI to provide the public with declassified information on how identified technologies pose national security risks.

Instead of punitively targeting one company, the RESTRICT Act gives us a framework to address the entire next generation of threats, giving us a smarter way to prepare for the ever-changing technological landscape.

What exactly are these threats? These are apps already on our phones, important parts of internet infrastructure, and software that underpins critical infrastructure. Continuing with the current approach jeopardizes our economy and our security.

The RESTRICT Act is a bipartisan solution that will allow us to address threats in a proactive, risk-based manner. It‚Äôll empower the Department of Commerce to identify and mitigate foreign threats to a range of critical communication tech.
